slides.notes: Introduce the topic with a punch. TypeScript is a powerful tool for scaling JavaScript development. This slide sets the tone for the session.

slides.title: 1. Leverage Type Safety
slides.content:
• Use strict mode in tsconfig.json for maximum type safety.
  • Define explicit types for function parameters and return values.
  • Avoid using any type to ensure better type checking.
slides.notes: Explain how strict mode ensures developers catch type-related issues early on, and highlight the importance of avoiding 'any'.

slides.title: 2. Use Interfaces and Types Wisely
slides.content:
Feature Interface Type
Object Shape ✅ Preferred ✅ Supported
Extending ✅ Easy ✅ Supported
Union Types ❌ Not Supported ✅ Preferred
slides.notes: Discuss when to use interfaces (e.g., for object structure) and when to use types (e.g., for unions or aliases). Emphasize the strengths of both.

slides.title: 3. Embrace Modern Features
slides.content:
• Use unknown instead of any for safer type assertions.
  • Adopt readonly for immutability where possible.
  • Leverage enum for clear and maintainable values.
slides.notes: Explain how modern TypeScript features help write more robust and maintainable code. Provide examples if time allows.

slides.title: 4. Avoid Common Pitfalls
slides.content:
• Don't overuse any or ! (non-null assertion).
  • Avoid mixing JavaScript and TypeScript files in the same project.
  • Be cautious with ts-ignore — it's a last resort.
slides.notes: Highlight common mistakes developers make when starting out with TypeScript. Stress the importance of clean, consistent practices.

slides.content:
"TypeScript is not about catching bugs, it's about making you a more productive developer."

— Anders Hejlsberg
slides.notes: End with an inspiring quote from the creator of TypeScript to leave the audience with a sense of purpose and motivation.
